editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Warden and Fellows of Merton College .

msItem.note: On f. ii are medical recipes in hands of s. xv and xvi; f. iiv blank. On f. iiiv is a title ‘Liber Marbodi de lapidibus’, s. xvii in.

msItem.title: Sententiae from Galen, Plato &c.
msItem.incipit: Sobrietas memoriam seruat
msItem.note: Followed by short notes fols. 1v-2: ‘Audi letando quid dicam uersificando ... si credis quod tenet usus’ (‘Versus de actibus et quantitate ponderum medicinalium’; WIC 1699, citing two German MSS); ‘De ponderibus et mensuris. Siclus et stater et denarius unum et idem sunt ...’ (eTK 1479I, citing only CCCC 481 [s. xiii], pp. 668–72); ‘De complexionibus humani corporis. Largus amans hilaris ridens rubeique coloris ... Humida geminus libra et aquarius feruet cancer aquatica scorpio piscis’ (‘De IV temperamentis’; WIC 10131, common in script and print).

msItem.author: ASCLEPIUS
msItem.title: Speculum Medicorum
msItem.rubric: Incipit prologus Asclepii quod dicitur speculum medicorum.
msItem.incipit: Ne tibi displiceat quod sic sum corpore paruus
Quia de egritudinibus singularum parcium corporis tractaturi sumus

msItem.author: Ps.-CLEOPATRA
msItem.title: Gynaecia
msItem.incipit: Incipiunt capitula
msItem.note: (Interrupted by the capitula of art. 5)
msItem.incipit: Humerose matricis signa sunt hec
msItem.explicit: et in lintheo inductum in positione. Explicit.
msItem.finalRubric: et in lintheo inductum in positione. Explicit
msItem.note: Pr. Basel 1566, Strassburg 1597; A. Beccaria, I Codici di Medicina del Periodo Presalernitano (Rome, 1956), p. 411; eTK 0645G. The same dislocation occurs in the probable exemplar, Bodl. Libr., e Mus. 219.

msItem.author: WALTER AGILON
msItem.title: De Retentione Menstruorum
msItem.rubric: Magister Walterus Agul’ de retencione menstruorum.
msItem.incipit: Regula. Vrina alba in colore tenuis in substantia

msItem.title: ‘TROTULA’, De Morbis Mulierum
msItem.incipit: Incipit prologus in librum Trotule de infirmitatibus mulierum et earum curis. Desideranti O filia karissima
Incipiunt capitula in librum Trotule de egritudinibus mulierum
(f. 99) Incipit prologus in librum Trocule de morbis mulierum et curis. Cum autor uniuersitatis Deus in prima mundi origine
msItem.explicit: sanguine draconis aluminis grana uue antiqua.
msItem.note: Often printed; eTK 0284J: M. H. Green, ‘The development of the Trotula’, Revue d’histoire des textes 26 (1996), 119–203; idem, ‘A handlist of the Latin and vernacular manuscripts of the so-called Trotula’, Scriptorium 50 (1996), 137–75, this copy at p. 162 (no. 79).

msItem.author: CONSTANTINE THE AFRICAN
msItem.title: De coitu
msItem.incipit: Incipiunt capitula in librum magistri Alexandri
Incipit liber Alexandri de coitu et eius effectu. Creator uolens omne genus firmiter ac stabiliter
msItem.note: Ed. E. Montero Cartelle (Monografías de la Universidad de Santiago de Compostela 77: Santiago de Compostela, 1983).

msItem.title: De phlebotomia
msItem.incipit: Incipiunt capitula in librum fleubothomie ...
Sanguis alius est naturalis alius non naturalis
msItem.note: The exemplar of this copy is Bodl. Libr., MS. e Mus. 219.

msItem.author: WALTER AGILON
msItem.title: De urinis
msItem.incipit: Incipiunt capitula magistri Walteri Agulini de urinis
msItem.note: Begins in tabular form, ‘Vrina calida intensa color rubeus ut crocus orientalis ... habet ypostasim in fundo

msItem.author: RICHARD THE ENGLISHMAN
msItem.title: Regulae de Vrinis (Micrologus, part II)
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt capitula in librum M. R. Salern. de urinis et febribus ...
msItem.incipit: Incipit liber Magistri Ricardi Salernie medici de hiis que sunt consideranda in omnibus urinis. Qui cupit urinas meas per compendia scire
msItem.note: The complete work ed. K. Sudhoff, Archiv für die Geschichte der Medizin 19 (1927), 209–39; eTK 1205G; Sharpe, Handlist, p. 472.

msItem.author: ALEXANDER
msItem.title: De Vrinis
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber de urinis secundum Magistrum Alexandrum.
msItem.incipit: Igitur a multis philosophorum describitur quod per urinas egritudinis iudicari possint
msItem.bibl: eTK 0656C, citing only the exemplar of this copy, Bodl. Libr., e Mus. 219.

msItem.author: Ps.-HIPPOCRATES
msItem.title: Epistola ad Maecenatum
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber Ypocratis de complexionibus urinis morbis et medicinis et de sanitate conseruanda regi Mecenati missus.
msItem.incipit: Libellum quem rogasti mihi
msItem.note: Ed. Corpus Medicorum Latinorum 5 (2 vols, Berlin, 2nd edn, 1968), pp. 26–32; eTK 0817K; Hippocrates Latinus, pp. 150–2, not this copy.

msItem.author: HIPPOCRATES
msItem.title: Experimenta
msItem.incipit: Sicut sunt quatuor tempora anni
msItem.explicit: In mense Februarii lauri baccas siccas coct’ et omnia ut supra.
msItem.note: eTK 1498F; Hippocrates Latinus, p. 165, not this copy. The work may end on f. 132v with ‘et adde mellis dissprimat xv. libris.’ Then ‘Item medicamenta ad sanitatem conseruanda’ followed by two columns of prose and verse, ‘Si uis ut homo per totum annum sanus et hilaris fiat’ and ‘Si uis incolumis si uis te uiuere sanum’ (eTK 1471F). Then ‘Item ad sanitatem conseruandam. Pono que utenda est per singulos menses exponimus atque ordinamus qualiter per unumquemque mensem et tempus ...’.

msItem.author: HIPPOCRATES
msItem.title: Ad Sanitatem Conseruandam
msItem.incipit: Mense Marcii dulce ieiunus bibe et dulce comede
msItem.note: cf. eTK 0868J; Hippocrates Latinus, p. 165, treats this as part of art. 12, but gives variants of this incipit at pp. 125–8, as De Cibis, or Calendarium Dieteticum.

msItem.author: HIPPOCRATES
msItem.title: De Vrinis
msItem.incipit: Corpus humanum patitur cotidie duo detrimenta
msItem.note: Unpr.; eTK 0269I, Hippocrates Latinus, p. 230, both citing only Bodl. Libr., e Mus. 219, the exemplar of this copy.

msItem.title: De Pulsibus
msItem.rubric: Incipit prologus in librum de pulsibus.
msItem.incipit: Qua te deuocione teneam mi Iohannes
Ad recognoscendum nature humane statum

msItem.author: ?COPHO
msItem.title: De Febribus
msItem.incipit: Quoniam humanum corpus ex quatuor humoribus constituitur
msItem.note: Ed. P. Capparoni (Rome, 1928), as Alfanus, De Quattuor Humoribus.

msItem.title: Experimenta Parui Alberti de Febribus
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt experimenta Parisii abbatis de febribus.
msItem.incipit: Sciendum est quod ex nimia ciborum comestione
msItem.note: Thorndike in Jnl. of the Hist. of Medicine 8 (1953), 263–83, at p. 275 n. 88.

msItem.title: Secretissimum Regis Cateni Persarum de Virtute Aquilae, transl. WILLIAM THE ENGLISHMAN
msItem.rubric: Liber de uirtute aquile. Secretissimum regis Cateni Persarum de uirtute aquile.
msItem.incipit: Est enim aquila rex omnium auium
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit iste tractatus a magistro Willelmo Anglico a lingua Arabica in Latinum translatus.
msItem.note: Unpr.; eTK 0508F; Sharpe,Handlist, p. 767. One of two copies, the other, Bodl. Libr., e Mus. 219, f. 142rv, the exemplar of this one.

msItem.author: ASCLEPIUS
msItem.title: De Animalibus
msItem.incipit: Regi Egipciorum Octouiano Augusto salutem. Pluribus exemplis tuam prudentiam cognoui
msItem.note: Pr. Basel 1541.

msItem.title: Quaestiones Naturales
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt questiones naturales arti phisice competentes.
msItem.incipit: Omnia corpora ex quatuor elementis composita habent quatuor qualitates

msItem.author: RICHARD THE ENGLISHMAN
msItem.title: Anatomia (Micrologus, part III), extr
msItem.incipit: Hic bene quadrifera distinguitur anathomia
Constituencia corporis humani tria sunt ..
msItem.note: The complete work ed. K. Sudhoff, Archiv für die Geschichte der Medizin 19 (1927), 209–39; eTK 0614I, 0258D, 0258E; Sharpe, Handlist, pp. 468–70. On the identity of the author, ibid., pp. 468, 519.

msItem.author: RICARDUS SALERNITANUS
msItem.title: Libellus de Vrinis et Febribus
msItem.rubric: Incipit pars quedam libri magistri Ricardi Salernitane de anathomia.
msItem.incipit: Quedam uene grosse que miro natura siathicam
msItem.explicit: ex quibus omnibus frigidiores esse monstrantur. Explicit.
msItem.note: Unpr.; eTK 1247I, one of three copies, all English. One of them, Bodl. Libr., e Mus. 219, fols. 117–22v, is the exemplar of this one.

msItem.author: GERARD OF CREMONA
msItem.title: Summa de Modo Medendi
msItem.incipit: Incipiunt capitula in summam magistri Geraldi
Cum omnis scientia ex fine et utilitate sua naturaliter sint appetenda

msItem.title: De Virtute Simplicium Medicinarum
msItem.rubric: Incipit prologus in librum de uirtute simplicis medicine.
msItem.incipit: Cogitanti mihi de simplicium medicamentarum uirtutibus uariis
msItem.note: capitula
msItem.incipit: Perfecte igitur temperate dicuntur illa
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber de uirtute simplicis medicine magistri Geraldi medici.
msItem.note: Pr. with Isaac Iudaeus, Opera, Lyon 1515, II, fols. 186v-9v; eTK 0229E, 1034E, 1034F, variously ascribed.

msItem.title: Practica Equorum
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber de practica equorum et aliorum animalium et auium.
msItem.incipit: Quoniam humana iocunditas in equorum incolumitate plurimum delectatur
msItem.bibl: eTK 1277E, citing only Bodl. Libr., e Mus. 219, the exemplar of this one.

msItem.author: MACER FLORIDUS (ODO OF MEUNG)
msItem.title: De Viribus Herbarum
msItem.note: Capitula f. 193rv
msItem.incipit: Herbarum quasdam dicturus carmine uates
msItem.explicit: Fit cataplasma ualeas membris quibus lesiuit ignis.
msItem.note: Ed. L. Choulant (Leipzig, 1832), pp. 28–123.

msItem.author: MARBOD
msItem.title: De Lapidibus
msItem.rubric: Incipit de generibus lapidum et nominibus et eorum uirtutibus.
msItem.incipit: Euax rex Arabum legitur scripsisse Neroni
msItem.explicit: Cui si non aliis placeant hec scripta Brunonis.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber Marbodi de lapidibus habens uersus septingentos xxx.

msItem.title: On the extraction of medicinal waters from flowers
msItem.incipit: Ad dissoluendum fleumaticos humores circa spiritualia. Extrahatur aqua de floribus ysopi lenistici
msItem.explicit: De discrasia scamosa. Extrahatur aqua de floribus uiolarum uel maluarum ...

msItem.incipit: Interpretaciones quorundam uerborum. Cephalica id est capitis dolor. Emeroyda
msItem.explicit: et a. r. s. m. p. o. &c.

msItem.incipit: De uermiculo. Si uis facere uermiculum accipe ampullam uitream et lima foris luto
msItem.note: Beg. as Mappae Clavicula: eTK 1470P; recipes for making colours, titles and incipits listed by L. Thorndike, ‘Some medieval texts on colours’, Ambix 7 (1959), 1–24, at pp. 6–7; M. Clarke, The Art of All Colours (London, 2001), no. 2740.

For arts 2–24 at least this is said to be a direct copy of Bodl. Libr., e Mus. 219 (Green, pp. 160–1, no. 73), written in England, s. xiii ex. The Bodl. MS begins impf., so might originally have contained art. 1 as well. After art. 23 it has three more arts not now in this one.

supportDesc.extent:
239 leaves of paper (iii + 236) 310 215
235 160
The edges heavily retrimmed with loss of marginalia. Water-mark bull-and-star.
supportDesc.foliation: Contemporary foliation in arabic numerals, repeating 44 and omitting 219.
supportDesc.collation: A bifolium, 1–1912, 2012(8–12 canc.); catchwords and leaf-numbers, often cropped.

layoutDesc.layout: Frame-ruled with crayon; written in c. 46 long lines.

handDesc.handNote: A single scribe, writing proficient Low Countries hybrida.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red initials, paraphs and highlighting (including the punctuation).

binding.p: s. xviii, marbled sides backed with calf, sewn on five bands. Fols. i and 236 are blank paper binding leaves. On fols. ii and 235 are the marks of five bosses. Parchment place-markers, cut mainly from a single MS, s. xiv, in a French cursive hand, project from the foredge.

history.provenance: At the head of f. 235v is ‘Iste est liber fratris Iohannis Hatfeld’, s. xv, and ‘Jhon Emes’, s. xvi, the second repeated on f. iii. At the head of f. ii is an erased inscription, ‘Liber fratris Willelmi ?Giffard’, and ‘MS. 2256’. On f. iii is ‘Liber fratris Thome Emery de Gadesddene’, smudged. In the margin of f. 123v is ‘Nota bene quod Bryg’’. Hatfield (BRUO 885) was monk of St Albans, scholar at Gloucester College in 1454 and 1456, prior of Belvoir until at least 1480.
At the foot of f. 1 is ‘L. Coll. Merton ex dono Car. King Art. Mag. et Coll. ejusdem Socii.’ Charles King was fellow of Merton 1684–1715.
Inside the front board is ‘Q. 1. 17’, canc. and replaced with ‘O. 1. 2 (CCCXXIV)’ in red; the College bookplate.

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Merton College Library.
